chargeHist.descr: Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent
Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent

result.execSummary:
The defendant Anthony F. Sylvester IV was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Take/Drive Veh. w/o Consent-Abandon Veh. [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(3m).
  • Theft-Movable Property <=$2500 [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Must set up a monthly payment plan with your probation agent to pay on restitution.  If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
Must maintain employment and must not leave or change employment without prior approval of probation agent.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  No contact with the victim in this case if probation agent deems appropriate.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  You must comply with any other recommendations of your probation agent.

timeConds.notes: Imposed and stayed as long as compliant with probation.  Jail credit to be determined.

supervisions.notes: A civil judgment is ordered for unpaid court ordered financial obligations.

records.addlTxt: Notice of Intent returned.  "Moved Left No Address"

Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Sebion.  Victim notification complied with.  Parties have the revocation packet.  No corrections or changes noted.  Credit due of 70 days per Attorney Sebion.   State concurrs.  State recommended:  6 months concurrent on each charge.  Convert balances due to civil judgment.  Defense recommended:  90 days concurrent on each count.  Time served.  Defendant exercised his right to allocution.  Court ordered:  6 months concurrent on each charge.  Credit for 70 days.  Judgment for unpaid court ordered financial obligations.
Sentencing hearing on revocation on March 20, 2018 at 04:00 pm.

Covers case No. 14CF28 and 13CF 209.  Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin. If currently impose to a jail term -he is to comply with all rules of huber if allowed.
